questions.text: Which type of X-ray film is most commonly used for high-detail imaging in Mammography? (NEET Pg 2016)
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A. Single Screen-Single Emulsion

 

Explanation: 

 

Mammographic X-ray tubes have specific characteristics that differentiate them from normal X-ray tubes. The entire mammography system is designed for high-detail imaging of breast tissue. Single Screen-Single Emulsion films are used in mammography because they provide the highest spatial resolution required for detecting small microcalcifications and subtle tissue changes.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Single Screen-Dual Emulsion - This film setup would not provide the optimal spatial resolution needed for mammography as dual emulsion films typically sacrifice some sharpness.

 

Option C. Dual Screen-Dual Emulsion - Using dual screens with dual emulsion would significantly reduce the resolution of the image, making it unsuitable for mammography where detection of minute details is critical.

 

Option D. Dual Screen-Single Emulsion - This combination would be impractical and inefficient, as dual screens would not properly expose a single emulsion film and would not provide the high detail needed for mammography.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Mammography requires specialized equipment including Single Screen-Single Emulsion film systems to achieve the high spatial resolution needed for detecting subtle abnormalities in breast tissue.

questions.text: In case of a prior history of neural tube defects, women in the preconception period should be advised to take: (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Folic acid

 

Folic acid is crucial for women in the preconception period, especially for those with a prior history of neural tube defects (NTDs). Neural tube defects are serious birth defects that affect the brain and spinal cord. The neural tube forms early in pregnancy, and folic acid, a B vitamin, plays a significant role in preventing these defects.

 

For women with a prior history of NTDs, the recommended dose of folic acid is higher than usual—4 milligrams (mg) per day. This higher dose is necessary because these women are at a greater risk of having another pregnancy affected by NTDs. Ideally, folic acid supplementation should begin at least 3 months before conception to maximize its protective effect.

 

This intervention is considered a form of primary prevention because it is aimed at preventing the occurrence of NTDs in pregnancies where the risk is already known due to a previous history.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Iron: Iron is important during pregnancy, but it does not have a direct role in preventing neural tube defects. It is typically recommended for preventing anemia.

 

Option B. Vitamin D: Vitamin D is crucial for bone health and immune function, but it is not specifically related to the prevention of neural tube defects.

 

Option D. Calcium: Calcium is vital for bone health, particularly for the developing fetus, but like iron and vitamin D, it is not involved in the prevention of neural tube defects.

 

Educational Objective:

 

For women with a prior history of neural tube defects, folic acid supplementation at a dose of 4 milligrams per day should be started at least 3 months before conception as a form of primary prevention.

choices.text: Plasmapheresis is not effective in refractory GBS
IV immunoglobulins are the first line of treatment
Areflexia in the weaker arm is included in diagnostic criteria

questions.text: Regarding Guillain-Barré syndrome (GBS) in children, which of the following statements is false? (INICET NOV 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Plasmapheresis is not effective in refractory GBS

 

Plasmapheresis (plasma exchange, PEX) is a well-established and effective treatment in GBS, including in refractory or severe cases. It is considered equivalent in efficacy to IVIG and may be used in patients not responding to IVIG (controversial, and sequential administration of PEX after IVIG is not recommended, but some clinicians try on a case-by-case basis), or if IVIG is contraindicated or unavailable.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. IV immunoglobulins are the first line of treatment: Correct. IVIG can be used as first-line treatment, having equal efficacy to plasma exchange in GBS management.

 

Option C. Areflexia in the weaker arm is included in diagnostic criteria: Correct. Areflexia in the weaker arm is a mandatory diagnostic criterion according to Brighton criteria. GBS is a demyelinating disease affecting large fibers that form the basis of reflex arcs.

 

Option D. Albumino-cytological dissociation: Correct. It is a classic feature of GBS, with high protein in CSF but normal cell count (<10 cells). Any cell count >50 essentially rules out GBS.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Plasmapheresis and IVIG are effective treatment options for GBS, including refractory cases, with neither being superior to the other. Never use immunosuppression or steroids in acute GBS.

 

 

Level of diagnostic certainty in Brighton criteria for GBS

questions.text: Identify the diagnosis based on this X-ray?  (INICET MAY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Patella fracture

 

  • The given image shows a comminuted patellar fracture with the fracture lines visible and moderate joint effusion.

 

 

PATELLA FRACTURE

 

  • Patellar fractures are usually caused by direct trauma, such as a fall from standing height onto the flexed knee or a dashboard impact from a motor vehicle collision.
  • These fractures can also be caused by rapid contracture of the quadriceps with a flexed knee that can lead to loss of the extensor mechanism.
  • Patella fractures account for 1% of all skeletal injuries and 6-9% are open fractures.
  • Male to female ratio is 2:1 and most fractures occur in 20-50 year olds.
  • On inspection, a palpable patellar defect, significant hemarthrosis, and lacerations, abrasions in setting of open fractures are found.
  • The patient has an inability to perform straight leg raise.
  • The extensor mechanism and retinaculum are disrupted.
  • Lateral view radiograph is the best view for transverse fractures. It is obtained in 30⁰ knee flexion.

 

Lateral view showing effusion in the knee

 

  • Axial view is the best view for vertical fractures.

 

 

  • An important differential diagnosis of patellar fracture is bipartite patella which can be mistaken as patella fracture. It shows smooth and regular borders on the radiograph; can be bilateral in 50% cases, and is characteristically seen in superolateral position.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Tibial Condyle fracture: Tibial Plateau fractures are periarticular injuries of the proximal tibia frequently associated with soft tissue injury. Incidence is 1-2% of all fractures. It can be caused in males in age group of 40s due to high energy trauma, and in females of age group of 70s due to low energy falls. Incidence of lateral plateau fracture is 70-80% (due to valgus load), bicondylar is 10-30% (due to axial load), and of medial plateau is 10-20% (due to varus load). In a high energy trauma, there is fracture-dislocation of the medial plateau with soft tissue injuries (meniscus and ACL tear, common peroneal nerve injury). Low energy traumas cause lateral plateau fractures. AP, lateral and oblique radiograph views are helpful; oblique view helps in determining amount of depression. AP view shows depressed articular surface and abnormal joint alignment. Lateral view shows posteromedial fracture lines and abnormal tibial slope.

 


AP and Lateral view showing tibial condyle/plateau fracture

 

Option B. Rheumatoid arthritis: Rheumatoid arthritis (RA) is a chronic inflammatory autoimmune disease of unknown etiology that affects approximately 1% of the world population, with approximately 50% of adults being unable to work within 10 years of disease onset. The disease involves synovial joints and leads to progressive joint destruction. The knee joint is commonly involved in RA. Severe destruction of the articular cartilage and menisci is a characteristic feature of RA. Bone marrow edema and bone erosion can both also be found, but are less characteristic.

 

 

Option D. Hemarthrosis of Knee Joint: Hemarthrosis is bleeding into a joint cavity. It is best diagnosed with arthrocentesis and synovial fluid analysis. Traumatic injury is the most common cause of hemarthrosis. Non-traumatic hemarthrosis can be caused by bleeding disorders that are either hereditary or acquired. Hereditary bleeding disorders include hemophilia and inherited coagulation factor deficiency disorders. Examples of acquired bleeding disorders include advanced liver or renal disease, vitamin K deficiency, disseminated intravascular coagulation, or anticoagulation medication use. Post-operative recurrent hemarthrosis is frequently associated with total knee arthroplasty. The preferred initial imaging modality is plain film radiology of the involved joint and surrounding bones. If a fracture is not seen but strongly suspected, further evaluation with a CT scan is warranted. MRI may be able to diagnose ligamentous or other soft tissue injuries as the cause of hemarthrosis. Ultrasound (US) can help identify and characterize intra-articular fluid collections. The synovial fluid from a hemarthrosis may appear red, pink, or brown depending on the cause of bleeding. Aspiration of the joint and subsequent analysis can differentiate simple effusion, hemarthrosis, lipohemarthrosis, and septic arthritis.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The given image shows the comminuted fracture of the patella.

questions.text: An infant with a history of multiple episodes of diarrhea presents with an erythematous, scaly rash, as shown in the image. Which nutritional deficiency is responsible for this condition, and which supplementation should be administered to reverse the clinical features? (FMGE JAN 2025)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Zinc

 

The case describes classic acrodermatitis enteropathica (AE), characterized by:

 

  • Presents around 6 months when weaning from breast milk occurs
  • Diagnostic triad: 
  1. Periorificial and acral dermatitis (erythematous scaly lesions)
  2. Diarrhea
  3. Alopecia
  • Caused by zinc deficiency due to SLC39A4 gene mutation
  • Inheritance: Autosomal recessive
  • Affects zinc absorption in intestine
  • Treatment requires lifelong zinc supplementation

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Vitamin A

 

  • Deficiency causes follicular hyperkeratosis
  • Does not present with periorificial dermatitis
  • No specific association with diarrhea
  • Different pattern of skin manifestations

 

Option C. Vitamin C

 

  • Deficiency causes scurvy
  • Presents with follicular hyperkeratosis and perifollicular hemorrhages
  • Characteristic corkscrew hair changes
  • Gum bleeding is prominent

 

 

Option D. Iron

 

  • Deficiency causes koilonychia (spoon-shaped nails)
  • Associated with angular cheilitis
  • Does not cause periorificial dermatitis
  • No direct association with diarrhea

 


 

Educational Objective: 


Acrodermatitis enteropathica presents with the triad of periorificial dermatitis, diarrhea, and alopecia due to zinc deficiency, requiring lifelong zinc supplementation.

questions.text: A woman in her reproductive age presented with a foul-smelling discharge, burning sensation, and lower abdominal pain. She also experiences dysuria. Pap smear is shown below. The organism responsible is: (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Trichomonas

 

The Ans.  is Trichomonas because the symptoms and the findings on the Pap smear point directly towards a Trichomonas infection. Trichomonas vaginalis is a protozoan parasite that commonly causes sexually transmitted infections characterized by a foul-smelling discharge, burning sensation, lower abdominal pain, and dysuria. The Pap smear often shows pear-shaped trophozoites with characteristic jerky movements, which are indicative of Trichomonas.

 

The key feature on the Pap smear that helps in identifying Trichomonas is the presence of these trophozoites. This, combined with the clinical symptoms described, strongly supports the diagnosis of Trichomoniasis.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. CMV (Cytomegalovirus): CMV infections are typically not sexually transmitted in this context and are not associated with foul-smelling vaginal discharge or the appearance seen on the Pap smear.

 

Option B. HPV (Human Papillomavirus): HPV can cause changes in the cervical cells seen on a Pap smear, but it does not cause the specific symptoms of foul-smelling discharge and burning sensation. HPV is more often linked with cervical dysplasia and warts.

 

Option C. HSV (Herpes Simplex Virus): HSV typically presents with painful vesicular lesions rather than a foul-smelling discharge and is not characterized by the pear-shaped trophozoites seen on the Pap smear.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Trichomonas vaginalis infection is characterized by a foul-smelling discharge, burning sensation, and the presence of pear-shaped trophozoites on a Pap smear.

questions.text: What is an absolute contraindication for attempting a vaginal birth after a previous Cesarean section? (NEET PG 2017)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Classical CS in first pregnancy

 

Previous classical cesarean section is an absolute contraindication for vaginal birth after cesarean (VBAC). Classical cesarean involves a vertical incision on the upper uterine segment, which has a significantly higher risk of rupture (4-9%) compared to the lower segment transverse incision (0.2-1.5%). The rupture of a classical scar can occur both during pregnancy and labor, making it unpredictable and potentially catastrophic.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Pregnancy Induced Hypertension: Incorrect. While pregnancy-induced hypertension is a complication that requires careful monitoring, it is not an absolute contraindication for VBAC. The decision would depend on the severity of hypertension, presence of other complications, and overall maternal and fetal wellbeing.

 

Option C. Grade 1 Placenta Praevia: Incorrect. Grade 1 placenta previa (low-lying placenta) may increase the risk during vaginal delivery, but it is not an absolute contraindication for VBAC. The management would depend on the exact location of the placenta in relation to the cervical os and previous uterine scar.

 

Option D. Mild Cephalopelvic Disproportion (CPD): Incorrect. Mild CPD may pose challenges for vaginal delivery, but it is not an absolute contraindication for VBAC. The decision would depend on careful assessment of the maternal pelvis, fetal size, and progression of labor.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Previous classical cesarean section carries a significantly higher risk of uterine rupture (4-9%) compared to lower segment transverse incision (0.2-1.5%), making it an absolute contraindication for attempting vaginal birth after cesarean delivery due to the unpredictable nature of rupture that can occur during both pregnancy and labor.

questions.text: The given congenital anomaly develops due to non-fusion of:  (FMGE Jan 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) 1st and 2nd pharyngeal arch

 

Explanation:

 

The image depicts a preauricular sinus, a congenital anomaly characterized by a small opening or pit near the external ear. This condition arises due to incomplete fusion during embryonic development.

 

  1. Embryological Development: The external ear develops from six small hillocks of tissue that form around the 1st pharyngeal cleft, derived from the 1st and 2nd pharyngeal arches. These hillocks eventually merge to form the pinna (external ear).
  2. Non-fusion of Pharyngeal Arches: If there is incomplete or improper fusion between the 1st and 2nd pharyngeal arches, a preauricular sinus may form. This sinus can present as a small pit or dimple in front of the ear and can sometimes become infected or form cysts.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. 2nd and 3rd pharyngeal arch: This is incorrect. The structures formed by the 2nd and 3rd pharyngeal arches do not contribute to the formation of the external ear and thus are not involved in the formation of preauricular sinuses.

 

Option C. 1st and 2nd pharyngeal pouch: This is incorrect. The pharyngeal pouches form internal structures such as the tonsils, thymus, and parts of the ear's auditory tube but are not involved in the formation of preauricular sinuses.

 

Option D. 3rd and 4th pharyngeal pouch: This is incorrect. These pouches are involved in forming structures like the thymus and parathyroid glands and do not play a role in the formation of the external ear or preauricular sinuses.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Preauricular sinuses result from the incomplete fusion of the 1st and 2nd pharyngeal arches during embryonic development, leading to the formation of a small pit or tract near the external ear.

questions.text: A 50-year-old male presented with vertigo, tinnitus and fluctuating hearing loss. The audiogram is given below. What is the most likely diagnosis based on the given image? (FMGE JANUARY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Meniere’s disease

 

Given the patient's symptoms of vertigo, tinnitus, and fluctuating hearing loss, along with the audiogram showing a sensorineural hearing loss pattern with a dip at low to mid frequencies, the most likely diagnosis is Option B, Meniere’s disease.

 

Meniere’s disease is characterized by episodes of vertigo, fluctuating hearing loss, tinnitus, and a feeling of fullness in the ear. The audiogram typically shows a sensorineural hearing loss that predominantly affects the low to mid frequencies, which is consistent with the audiogram provided.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. BPPV (Benign Paroxysmal Positional Vertigo): Is a disorder arising from a problem in the inner ear. Symptoms include vertigo that is usually triggered by changes in the position of the head. It doesn't typically cause hearing loss, which we can see in the audiogram.

 

Option C. Vestibular neuronitis: Is an inflammation of the vestibular nerve, leading to vertigo and imbalance, but it does not usually affect hearing, so the audiogram would not show the hearing loss pattern we see here.

 

Option D. Otosclerosis: Is a middle ear disease that usually presents with conductive hearing loss, particularly in younger adults, and it does not cause vertigo or tinnitus as primary symptoms. The audiogram for otosclerosis would show an air-bone gap, which is not present in the audiogram provided.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The most likely diagnosis for a patient presenting with vertigo, tinnitus, fluctuating hearing loss, and an audiogram showing low to mid frequency sensorineural hearing loss is Meniere’s disease.

questions.text: A patient develops prosthetic valve endocarditis 2 years after valve replacement surgery. Which of the following organisms is the most likely cause? (NEET PG 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Streptococcus

 

Streptococcus, particularly Streptococcus viridans, is the most likely cause of prosthetic valve endocarditis (PVE) occurring late (more than 12 months after surgery). In the context of PVE, late cases are often similar to native valve endocarditis where Streptococcus viridans is a common pathogen due to its ability to adhere to damaged heart valves and form biofilms. The presentation of endocarditis 2 years post-surgery aligns with this etiological pattern.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Staphylococcus aureus: While a common cause of early prosthetic valve endocarditis (within the first 2 months), its prevalence decreases as the time post-surgery increases.

 

Option C. Coagulase negative staphylococci (CONS): These are more typical in early PVE cases, often within the first 2 months post-surgery, associated with intraoperative contamination.

 

Option D. HACEK organisms: These are a less common cause of endocarditis and are generally not the leading pathogens in prosthetic valve infections.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Prosthetic Valve Endocarditis:

 

  • Early (< 2 months): CONS > S. Aureus
  • Late (> 2-12 months): Similar to native valve -S. viridans

choices.text: Increased lung volume, Increased thoracic volume
Decreased lung volume, Increased thoracic volume
Decreased lung volume, thoracic volume remains unaffected
Lung volume remains unaffected, Decreased thoracic volume

questions.text: A 43-year-old male presented with right-sided rib pain and shortness of breath. A chest X-ray showed a significant right-sided pneumothorax with cardio-mediastinal shift to the left. Which of the following changes will be seen? (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Decreased lung volume, Increased thoracic volume

 

In a pneumothorax, air enters the pleural space, leading to a loss of negative pressure that normally keeps the lung inflated. This causes the affected lung to collapse, significantly decreasing its volume. Concurrently, the thoracic cavity compensates by expanding due to the increase in pressure within the pleural space. This expansion is often accompanied by a mediastinal shift towards the unaffected side, in this case, the left side, as seen in the X-ray. The increase in thoracic volume occurs as the chest wall expands outward due to the absence of opposing forces from the collapsed lung.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Increased lung volume, Increased thoracic volume: This option is incorrect because in pneumothorax, the lung volume decreases due to collapse, not increases.

 

Option C. Decreased lung volume, thoracic volume remains unaffected: This is incorrect because, although lung volume decreases, the thoracic volume typically increases as the pleural cavity expands.

 

Option D. Lung volume remains unaffected, Decreased thoracic volume: This is incorrect because pneumothorax leads to a decrease in lung volume and an increase in thoracic volume, not a decrease.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In a pneumothorax, the affected lung collapses leading to decreased lung volume, while the thoracic volume increases due to the loss of negative pleural pressure and the expansion of the thoracic cavity.

questions.text: Which of the following features of tuberous sclerosis is typically present during infancy but resolves by adulthood? (NEET PG 2015)
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A. Rhabdomyomas of the heart

 

Explanation:

 

Rhabdomyomas of the heart are benign tumors that represent one of the earliest manifestations of tuberous sclerosis. These cardiac tumors are typically present during fetal life or early infancy but have a tendency to spontaneously regress with age. The majority of cardiac rhabdomyomas associated with tuberous sclerosis resolve by childhood or early adulthood, often without causing significant clinical problems. While present, they can cause arrhythmias or outflow obstruction, but their natural history is typically one of regression rather than progression.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Angiofibromas on the face: These lesions (formerly called adenoma sebaceum) typically appear during childhood (around 3-5 years of age) and persist throughout adulthood. They are reddish-brown papules that appear in a butterfly distribution across the face and tend to increase in number and size during adolescence rather than resolving.

 

Option C. Fibromas around the nails: Periungual fibromas (Koenen tumors) typically appear during adolescence or early adulthood and persist rather than resolve. These flesh-colored nodules emerge from the nail folds, primarily of the toes but sometimes the fingers.

 

Option D. Angiomyolipomas in the kidneys: Renal angiomyolipomas are benign tumors that typically appear during childhood or adolescence and continue to grow throughout adulthood. They do not spontaneously regress and may require monitoring or intervention if they grow large or cause symptoms.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

Cardiac rhabdomyomas are unique among the major manifestations of tuberous sclerosis in that they typically appear in early life and have a natural history of spontaneous regression, while most other tuberous sclerosis lesions persist or progress over time.

questions.text: Sequence of Rigor Mortis is: (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Head to foot

 

Rigor mortis is the postmortem stiffening of muscles due to biochemical changes in the muscle tissues after death. It typically starts within 2 hours after death, beginning with the myocardium (heart muscle). Externally, the sequence begins at the upper eyelids and then follows a top-to-bottom approach throughout the body.

 

The progression of rigor mortis occurs in three stages:

 

  • Developing Stage (First 12 hours): Rigor begins at the upper parts of the body and progresses downwards.
  • Fully Developed Stage (Next 12 hours): Rigor mortis is fully established.
  • Passing Stage (Last 12 hours): Rigor mortis diminishes in the same order, starting from the head and moving downwards, eventually leading to secondary flaccidity.

 

This sequence is known as Nysten's Rule, which describes rigor mortis development from head to foot, with the exact order being eyelids, neck, jaw, face, chest, upper limbs, abdomen, lower limbs, and finally fingers and toes.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Centre to periphery: This option incorrectly suggests that rigor mortis progresses from the center of the body outward, which does not align with the actual top-to-bottom sequence of rigor mortis development.

 

Option C. Foot to head: This option is incorrect as rigor mortis follows a head-to-foot sequence, not the reverse.

 

Option D. Periphery to centre: This option is incorrect because rigor mortis does not start at the outer parts of the body and move inward; instead, it progresses from the head down towards the feet.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Rigor mortis follows a sequence known as Nysten's Rule, developing and passing from head to foot, starting with the upper body and ending with the lower extremities.

choices.text: Iron prophylaxis is given for 6 months antepartum and 6 months postpartum
Iron prophylaxis is started at 14 weeks and continued for 6 weeks after delivery
Iron prophylaxis starts in the 1st trimester and continues till 6 weeks postpartum
Iron prophylaxis is given 6 months antepartum and 3 months postpartum

questions.text: As per Anemia Mukt Bharat, which is the correct statement regarding iron prophylaxis in pregnant women? (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Iron prophylaxis is given for 6 months antepartum and 6 months postpartum

 

Explanation:

 

The Anemia Mukt Bharat (AMB) initiative outlines that iron prophylaxis for pregnant women should start from the 14th week of pregnancy and continue throughout the pregnancy (approximately 6 months) and for 6 months postpartum. The recommended dosage is one red-colored, sugar-coated tablet containing 60 mg of elemental iron and 0.5 mg of folic acid daily. This regimen helps in preventing iron deficiency anemia and folate deficiency anemia during and after pregnancy.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Iron prophylaxis for pregnant women under the Anemia Mukt Bharat initiative is given from 14 weeks of pregnancy and continues for 6 months postpartum.

questions.text: Identify the given sign:(NEET PG 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Popeye sign

 

  • This image shows typical finding on physical examination, which is caused by bulging of the biceps muscle belly after rupture of the biceps tendon, known as Popeye sign or Popeye deformity.
  • The Popeye is a cartoon character with bulging muscles, hence its name.

 

POPEYE SIGN

 

  • Etiology:
    • Due to sudden eccentric biomechanical load is applied with the forearm flexed and supinated, which can cause the rupture of either the proximal or the distal tendon junctions.
       
  • Risk factors: 
    • Older age
    • Smoking habit
    • Usage of certain drugs (corticosteroids, statins).
    • Shoulder overuse (sports or work-related activities).

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Inverted champagne bottle sign. This sign is seen in Lipodermatosclerosis, also referred to as sclerosing panniculitis or hypodermitis sclerodermaformis, which is a persistent inflammatory disorder characterized by the development of subcutaneous fibrosis and induration of the skin of the lower extremities. The chronic phase of lipodermatosclerosis is characterized by well-defined, circumferential, thick, darkly pigmented, non-tender plaques. These plaques are described as having a firm, “woody” induration, and the sclerotic change with circumferential narrowing of the lower leg and concurrent proximal and distal edema, that produces the classic “inverted champagne bottle” appearance of the lower extremity. The rounded cork of the champagne bottle is symbolic of the edematous foot, the central fibrosis around the ankle represents the neck, and the bottle's body embodies the lymphedema proximal to the area of constriction.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The image shown in the question is called Popeye Sign, which is visible on elbow flexion due to bicipital tendonitis.

questions.text: Identify the muscle forming the marked boundary: (FMGE JANUARY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Extensor pollicis longus

 

Explanation:

 

The image shows the anatomical snuff box, a triangular depression at the base of the thumb. The anatomical snuff box has specific boundaries, and the arrow is pointing to the posterior (posteromedial) boundary. The muscle forming the posterior boundary of the anatomical snuff box is the extensor pollicis longus.

 

 

The mnemonic "aage longus peechhe longus beech mein brevis" helps remember the boundaries:

 

  • Anterior (anterolateral) boundary: Abductor pollicis longus and extensor pollicis brevis
  • Posterior (posteromedial) boundary: Extensor pollicis longus
  • Between the two boundaries: Extensor pollicis brevis

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Extensor pollicis brevis: This muscle forms part of the anterior boundary and the floor of the anatomical snuff box, not the posterior boundary.

 

Option B. Abductor pollicis longus: This muscle forms part of the anterior boundary of the anatomical snuff box, not the posterior boundary.

 

Option C. Abductor pollicis brevis: This muscle is not related to the boundaries of the anatomical snuff box. It is a muscle of the thenar eminence, responsible for abduction of the thumb.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The extensor pollicis longus forms the posterior boundary of the anatomical snuff box.

questions.text: Voltage-gated calcium channel present on T-tubule is: (FMGE JANUARY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Dihydropyridine receptor

 

Explanation:

 

The T-tubules, or transverse tubules, are invaginations of the sarcolemma (muscle cell membrane) that play a crucial role in transmitting action potentials from the sarcolemma to the interior of the muscle fiber.

 

The voltage-gated calcium channels present on the T-tubules are known as dihydropyridine receptors (DHPR). These receptors are critical for the excitation-contraction coupling in muscle cells.

 

Dihydropyridine receptor: These receptors are voltage-gated calcium channels located on the T-tubules. When an action potential travels down the T-tubule, it activates the DHPR, which in turn mechanically activates the ryanodine receptor (RYR) on the sarcoplasmic reticulum, leading to the release of calcium ions into the cytoplasm and triggering muscle contraction.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Ryanodine receptor: This receptor is also involved in calcium release but is located on the sarcoplasmic reticulum, not on the T-tubules. It is mechanically coupled to the DHPR in skeletal muscle.

 

Option C. SERCA: The Sarcoplasmic/Endoplasmic Reticulum Calcium ATPase (SERCA) pump is responsible for pumping calcium back into the sarcoplasmic reticulum, but it is not located on the T-tubules.

 

Option D. Nicotinic receptor: These are ligand-gated cation channels located at the neuromuscular junction on the sarcolemma, not on the T-tubules. They are responsible for initiating the action potential in response to acetylcholine but are not involved in calcium transport in the T-tubules.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The voltage-gated calcium channel present on the T-tubules is the dihydropyridine receptor (DHPR), which plays a crucial role in the excitation-contraction coupling in muscle cells.

questions.text: A patient with pauci-immune crescentic glomerulonephritis, palpable purpura, myalgia, and pulmonary hemorrhage was found to have p-ANCA positivity. Which of the following is the likely vasculitis in him? (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Microscopic polyangiitis

 

Microscopic polyangiitis (MPA) is a type of small-vessel vasculitis that is commonly associated with p-ANCA (MPO-ANCA) positivity.

 

MPA is characterized by multi-organ involvement, including pauci-immune crescentic glomerulonephritis (kidney involvement), palpable purpura (skin involvement), myalgia (muscle involvement), and pulmonary hemorrhage (lung involvement).

 

The presence of p-ANCA is a key diagnostic feature that differentiates MPA from other types of vasculitides.

 

MPA does not usually form granulomas, which is a distinguishing factor from granulomatosis with polyangiitis (Wegener’s), another ANCA-associated vasculitis. The constellation of symptoms and p-ANCA positivity points directly toward MPA as the diagnosis.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Granulomatosis with polyangiitis (GPA): This condition is typically associated with c-ANCA (PR3-ANCA) positivity, not p-ANCA. Additionally, GPA often presents with granulomatous inflammation, which is not seen in MPA.

 

Option C. Polyarteritis nodosa (PAN): PAN involves medium-sized arteries and typically spares the lungs. It is not associated with ANCA positivity, and patients with PAN do not usually present with glomerulonephritis or pulmonary hemorrhage.

 

Option D. Behcet disease: This condition is an inflammatory disorder characterized by recurrent oral and genital ulcers, uveitis, and skin lesions. It is associated with the presence of anti-endothelial or anti-enolase antibodies.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Microscopic polyangiitis (MPA) is a small-vessel vasculitis associated with p-ANCA positivity and multi-organ involvement, including the kidneys, skin, muscles, and lungs

 

p-ANCA Positive Conditions:

 

 

Comparison of c-ANCA vs p-ANCA:

questions.text: A 55-year-old man presented with cough and congestion in the chest. He is a known case of atrial fibrillation (AF) and on examination, he had an irregularly irregular pulse and ECG showed AF with a heart rate of 52/min. His current medications are KCl 10 mEq BID, Triamterene, ASA 100mg/day, Atenolol 50 mg BID, and Clarithromycin. Two months ago, his digoxin levels were 1.5 ng/mL and currently, it rose to 3.4 ng/mL. Which of the following is responsible for such an increase in digoxin levels? (NEET PG 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Clarithromycin

 

The patient is experiencing elevated digoxin levels, which is likely due to a drug-drug interaction. Digoxin is a medication used to treat various heart conditions, including atrial fibrillation. It has a narrow therapeutic index, meaning that even small changes in its levels can lead to toxicity.

 

Clarithromycin is a macrolide antibiotic that inhibits the enzyme cytochrome P450 3A4 (CYP3A4). Digoxin is partially metabolized by CYP3A4. When clarithromycin inhibits this enzyme, it can lead to decreased metabolism of digoxin, resulting in elevated digoxin levels and potential toxicity. This interaction can explain the significant increase in the patient's digoxin levels from 1.5 ng/mL to 3.4 ng/mL.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Triamterene: Triamterene is a potassium-sparing diuretic and does not typically interact with digoxin in a way that would cause elevated digoxin levels. It is not known to inhibit the metabolism of digoxin.

 

Option B. KCl: Potassium chloride (KCl) supplementation is often given to prevent hypokalemia, which can enhance the toxic effects of digoxin. However, KCl does not directly interact with digoxin to increase its serum levels. Instead, it helps mitigate digoxin toxicity by maintaining normal potassium levels.

 

Option D. Atenolol: Atenolol is a beta-blocker and does not interact with digoxin to increase its serum levels. While it can affect heart rate, it does not interfere with the metabolism or excretion of digoxin.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Clarithromycin, by inhibiting CYP3A4, can significantly elevate digoxin levels, leading to toxicity. When prescribing medications, it is essential to consider potential drug-drug interactions, especially with drugs like digoxin that have a narrow therapeutic index.

questions.text: Sylvian Point is related to: (NEET PG 2015)
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D (Lateral Cerebral Sulcus)

 

Explanation: 

 

The Sylvian Point is anatomically related to the lateral cerebral sulcus, also known as the Sylvian fissure. This important anatomical structure is bilaterally symmetric, contains cerebrospinal fluid (CSF), and serves as the boundary that separates the temporal lobe from the frontal and parietal lobes. The Sylvian point specifically refers to a landmark point on this sulcus, which is a critical reference point in neuroanatomy and neuroimaging.

 

 

Other Options: 

 

Option A. Central Sulcus - The central sulcus separates the frontal lobe from the parietal lobe and contains the motor and sensory cortices. It has no direct relationship with the Sylvian point, which is associated with the lateral cerebral sulcus.

 

Option B. Calcarian Sulcus - The calcarine sulcus is located in the medial aspect of the occipital lobe and contains the primary visual cortex. It is not related to the Sylvian point or the lateral sulcus anatomy.

 

Option C. Petro-occipital Sulcus - This sulcus is located at the junction of the petrous portion of the temporal bone and the occipital bone. It has no relationship with the Sylvian point, which is a cortical landmark.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The Sylvian point is related to the lateral cerebral sulcus (Sylvian fissure), which is an important bilateral CSF-containing space that separates the temporal lobe from the frontal and parietal lobes and serves as a critical landmark in neuroanatomy and neuroradiology.

questions.text: A 42-year-old woman presents with a rapidly growing, painless mass in her right breast that she first noticed about 3 months ago. On physical examination, the mass is well-circumscribed, lobulated, and larger than 5 cm in diameter. A history of a similar lesion occurred 2 years back also. A core needle biopsy is performed, and the histological examination reveals the image as shown. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis? (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Phyllodes tumor

 

Phyllodes tumor is a rare breast tumor that typically presents in middle-aged women (fourth to fifth decade). It is characterized by rapid growth, a lobulated appearance, and often exceeds 5 cm in diameter.

 

Phyllodes tumors can be distinguished from fibroadenomas by their stromal overgrowth and the presence of characteristic leaf-like projections seen in histological examinations. The image shows a stromal tumor with these classical leaf-like projections, confirming the diagnosis of Phyllodes tumor.

 

Phyllodes tumors can recur and have a low risk of becoming malignant, setting them apart from benign fibroadenomas and malignant carcinomas.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Invasive ductal carcinoma: This is the most common type of breast cancer, characterized by a solid mass with irregular borders. It typically presents with more aggressive features, such as lymphovascular invasion, which are absent in this case. The histology does not show the leaf-like stromal projections seen in Phyllodes tumors.

 

Option C. Fibroadenoma: A common benign breast tumor seen mostly in younger women, characterized by a well-circumscribed, mobile mass. Histologically, it shows a mix of glandular and stromal elements but lacks the prominent stromal overgrowth and leaf-like projections seen in Phyllodes tumors.

 

Option D. Ductal papilloma: This benign tumor involves the breast ducts and often presents with nipple discharge rather than a large, rapidly growing mass. The histological appearance is distinct from that of Phyllodes tumors, lacking the stromal and leaf-like characteristics.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Phyllodes tumors are rapidly growing, lobulated breast masses with characteristic leaf-like stromal projections on histology, commonly seen in middle-aged women, and may recur.

questions.text: Which of the following middle ear structure is a derivative of neural crest cells?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Foot plate of stapes

 

The malleus, incus, and stapes are the three ossicles of the middle ear that transmit sound vibrations from the eardrum to the inner ear. 

 

The footplate of the stapes is the portion of the stapes that sits in the oval window of the cochlea. It is unique among the ossicles because its development involves contributions from neural crest cells.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Malleus: Develops from the first branchial (pharyngeal) arch, also known as Meckel's cartilage, which is not derived from neural crest cells.

 

Option B. Stapes: While it is part of the same series of ossicles as the malleus, the main structure of the stapes develops from the second branchial (pharyngeal) arch, known as Reichert's cartilage, which is also not derived from neural crest cells.

 

Option D. Incus: Like the malleus, is derived from the first pharyngeal arch. It too is not a derivative of neural crest cells.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The footplate of the stapes in the middle ear is the structure derived from neural crest cells, distinguishing it from the other ossicles (malleus and incus), which are derived from the first and second pharyngeal arches and not from neural crest cells.

questions.text: The primary type of collagen found in tendons is: (NEET PG 2015)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Type I

 

Explanation:

 

Type I collagen is the most abundant type of collagen found in the human body and is the primary collagen type present in tendons. Type I collagen is located in the skin and is the most abundant collagen type. Tendons are dense connective tissues that connect muscles to bones and require the high tensile strength that Type I collagen provides.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Type II: This type of collagen is found primarily in cartilage and connective tissue.

 

Option C. Type III: This type of collagen is primarily found in arteries and the cardiovascular system.

 

Option D. Type IV: This type of collagen is found in basement membranes, particularly in the glomerulus of the kidney. It forms sheet-like structures rather than the fibrillar structure needed for tendons.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

Type I collagen is the most abundant collagen in the human body and provides the high tensile strength required for structures like tendons, skin, and bones, with a characteristic triple-helical structure that contributes to its exceptional strength.

questions.text: In the medical management of glaucoma, drugs which decrease the intraocular pressure are indicated. Which of the following drugs decreases intraocular pressure by increasing uveoscleral flow? (NEET PG 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Latanoprost

 

  • Latanoprost is a prostaglandin drug used to lower intraocular pressure.
  • It works by increasing uveoscleral outflow.
  • Latanoprost is a prodrug that is activated during its passage through the cornea.
  • It stimulates prostanoid receptors on ciliary muscles, leading to the release of matrix metalloproteinases.
  • Matrix metalloproteinases increase uveoscleral outflow.

 

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Timolol: This is a non-selective beta-blocker that decreases intraocular pressure by reducing aqueous humor production. It does not significantly affect uveoscleral outflow.

 

Option C. Pilocarpine: A miotic agent that increases trabecular outflow but does not have a significant effect on uveoscleral outflow. It works by constricting the pupil and contracting the ciliary muscle.

 

Option D. Carbonic anhydrase inhibitors (e.g., acetazolamide, dorzolamide): These drugs decrease intraocular pressure by inhibiting the enzyme carbonic anhydrase, thereby reducing the production of aqueous humor. They do not affect uveoscleral outflow.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Latanoprost, a prostaglandin analogue, lowers intraocular pressure by increasing the uveoscleral outflow of aqueous humor, making it an effective treatment option for glaucoma.

questions.text: A 16-year-old patient presents with pellagra-like symptoms. There was no history of flushing and urinary 5-HIAA levels were normal. Family history of similar illness was noted. What is the diagnosis? (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Hartnup disease

 

Hartnup disease is an autosomal recessive disorder caused by defective transport of neutral or non-polar amino acids, particularly tryptophan, in the intestines and kidneys. This defect leads to decreased absorption and increased urinary excretion of these amino acids, resulting in tryptophan deficiency. Tryptophan is a precursor for niacin (vitamin B3), serotonin, and melatonin. Deficiency in tryptophan can therefore lead to niacin deficiency, manifesting as pellagra-like symptoms.

 

Unlike Fanconi syndrome, which is characterized by non-selective amino aciduria (excretion of various amino acids including proline, hydroxyproline, and arginine), Hartnup disease typically shows selective amino aciduria, primarily affecting tryptophan and similar neutral amino acids.

 

Key indicators in this case include:

 

  • Pellagra-like symptoms: Dermatitis, diarrhea, and dementia, commonly associated with niacin deficiency.
  • No history of flushing and normal urinary 5-HIAA levels: These findings rule out carcinoid syndrome, which is characterized by flushing and elevated 5-HIAA levels due to serotonin overproduction.
  • Family history of similar illness: Suggests a genetic disorder, consistent with the autosomal recessive inheritance pattern of Hartnup disease.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Carcinoid: Typically presents with flushing, diarrhea, and elevated urinary 5-HIAA levels due to serotonin overproduction. These findings are absent here.

 

Option C. Nutritional pellagra: Caused by dietary niacin deficiency. The presence of a family history of similar symptoms makes a genetic cause more likely than a nutritional deficiency.

 

Option D. Essential fructosuria: A benign condition caused by a defect in fructokinase, leading to fructose excretion in urine. It does not cause pellagra-like symptoms.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Hartnup disease should be considered in patients with pellagra-like symptoms, particularly if there is a family history of similar symptoms and no evidence of carcinoid syndrome or nutritional deficiency. 

 

Elevated levels of neutral amino acids like tryptophan in the urine are a hallmark of Hartnup disease, indicating an issue with amino acid reabsorption in the kidneys.
